metadata.title: 3D printing of concentrated alginate/gelatin scaffolds with homogeneous nano apatite coating for bone tissue engineering

sections.text:
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
mechanical properties and desirable bioactivity are promising for bone tissue engineering. Here, concentrated alginate/gelatin scaffolds with homogeneous nano apatite coating were developed utilizing 3D printing and in situ mineralization. The thickness of nano apatite coating was controlled by adjusting the amount of phosphate ions in the printing inks. The alginate/gelatin scaffolds with uniform nano apatite coating had 2-fold higher Young’s modulus compared with the scaffolds without apatite coating. In addition, nano apatite coating significantly stimulated the proliferation and osteogenic differentiation of rat bone marrow stem cells. Furthermore, nano apatite coating increased the protein adsorption on the surface of scaffolds. The fabricated biomimetic nano apatite/hydrogel composite scaffolds would be potential candidates for bone tissue engineering. Key words: Nano apatite, 3D printing, Mineralization, Bone tissue engineering
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The repair of large bone defects remains a big clinical challenge. Continuous efforts have been made in this field including the fabrication of biomimetic bone scaffolds [1]. Various biomaterials including bioceramics and polymers have been utilized to prepare scaffolds for bone tissue engineering [2]. For instance, synthetic polymers such as poly(lactic acid) (PLA) [3], poly(ɛ-caprolactone) (PCL) [4] and poly (lactic-co-glycolic) acid (PLGA) [5] with good biocompatibility and suitable mechanical strength have been developed as bone scaffolds using various techniques. Additionally, natural biopolymers such as collagen, gelatin and chitosan with excellent biocompatibility and abundant of cell recognition sites are promising candidates for tissue engineering application [6,7]. However, the mechanical properties of natural polymers are generally low for bone tissue engineering application [8]. Recently, it has been shown that interpenetrating networks consisting of two or more interlocked polymers exhibited improved mechanical properties [9]. However, the interpenetrating hydrogels are still mechanically weak for bone tissue engineering due to their low polymer concentrations and high water content [10]. Our previous study showed that alginate/gelatin composite scaffolds with high polymer concentration (16.7 wt%) after dual crosslinking presented enhanced mechanical properties [11]. However, bone scaffolds not only need to have suitable mechanical properties, but also should possess desirable bioactivity for promoting osteogenic differentiation of stem cells [12,13]. Hydroxyapatite (HA), the major inorganic component of natural
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
bone, is expected to have good bioactivity, and it has been applied widely in bone tissue engineering [14]. Direct mixing nano/micro HA particles within polymer solution is the general method to prepare HA/polymer composite scaffolds [15]. However, direct mixing is difficult to control the distribution of HA particles in polymer matrices. Precipitation from simulated body fluid (SBF) is another widely used strategy to build nano HA/polymer composites [16, 17]. For example, nano apatite-like structures were observed on the surface of alginate/gelatin/silica composite after soaking into 1.5×SBF over 7 days [18]. However, incubation of polymer scaffolds in SBF for achieving nano apatite deposition is a time-consuming process. Several days to weeks are generally required for depositing nano apatite on the surface of polymer scaffolds. In addition, long term incubation in SBF leads to partial degradation of polymer and also alters the characteristics for any encapsulated therapeutic agents [19]. In situ mineralization or in situ precipitation is an effective method to construct polymer/HA composite [20]. In this method, polymer solution containing phosphate (or calcium) ions was dropped into calcium (or phosphate) solution, or polymers were immersed in a solution of calcium chloride and sodium dihydrogen phosphate anhydrous with a Ca/P ratio of 1.67. Then, the reaction between calcium and phosphate ions took place leading to the formation of apatite in the polymer matrices [21,22]. This method has been demonstrated to be efficient in mineralizing homogeneously distributed nano apatite in polymer matrices [23]. Collagen/nano HA [24], alginate/nano HA [25], gelatin/nano HA [26] and chitosan/nano HA composites
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
[27] have been fabricated through this method. However, according to our knowledge, there were no reports on the fabrication of alginate/gelatin interpenetrating 3D scaffolds with homogeneous nano apatite coating for bone tissue engineering using this method. Herein, concentrated alginate/gelatin composite scaffolds with homogeneous nano apatite coating and pre-designed structures were fabricated via 3D printing and in situ mineralization. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM), Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) were used to characterize the prepared scaffolds. The swelling ratio, mechanical properties, osteogenic differentiation and protein adsorption of fabricated scaffolds were also investigated.

sections.heading: 2. Materials and methods
sections.text:
2.1 Preparation of scaffolds
The bioinks for 3D printing of scaffolds were prepared according the following steps. Firstly, 10 wt% gelatin solution was prepared by dissolving gelatin (Sigma-Aldrich) in 0.1 M or 0.5 M Na2HPO4 solution (preheated to 60 ºC) under magnetic stirring. After gelatin was completely dissolved, 6 g of as-prepared hot gelatin/Na2HPO4 solution was mixed with 1 g of alginate (Sigma-Aldrich). The mixture was stirred vigorously until homogeneous pastes were achieved. Finally, the prepared bioinks were loaded into printing tube equipped with heating system. Scaffolds with pre-designed morphology (lattice) and size (10×10×5 mm, Ф5×2 mm and Ф10×10 mm) were fabricated via 3D printing system (Bioscaffolder 3.1, Gesim, Germany) under 55ºC. The printing speed was set at 5 mm/min by applying air
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
pressure of 0.5 MPa through printing needle having an inner diameter of 610 μm. As control, 10 wt% gelatin solution was prepared by dissolving gelatin in 0.1 M NaCl instead of Na2HPO4 solution, and then 6 g of as-prepared hot gelatin/NaCl solution was mixed with 1 g of alginate. After the control bioink was stirred homogeneously, the control scaffolds (alginate/gelatin) were also fabricated according to the same parameters. Afterwards, all of the fabricated scaffolds were soaked in 1 M CaCl2 solution (pH=9) for 20 min at room temperature. After washing and drying, the scaffolds were incubated into a solution of 2 wt % N-(3-dimethylaminopropyl)-N-ethylcarbodiimide (EDC) and 0.25 wt % N-hydroxysuccinimide (NHS) over night. Finally, the crosslinked scaffolds were thoroughly washed by deionized water for three times and dried at room temperature for further use.
2.2 Characterization of scaffolds
The pore size and morphology of prepared scaffolds were characterized by light microscopy (Stemi 2000-C, Zeiss). The micro and nano features of scaffolds were analyzed by scanning electron microscope (SEM) and energy dispersive spectrometry (EDS) (SU-70, Hitachi). The samples were coated with gold before SEM analysis. In addition, the scaffolds were ground into fine powder and pressed into a KBr pellet, and characterized by FTIR (Spectrum Two, PerkinElmer). Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) (TGA Q50) was performed between room temperature to 600 ºC with heating rate of 10 ºC/min in air, using TG apparatus.
2.3 Swelling behavior measurement
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
Dry scaffolds were soaked in deionized water at 37 °C under gently shaking. At 1 and 3 h, four samples for each type of scaffold were taken out and put on a filter paper for seconds to remove the water from open pores, and then weighed. The swelling ratio of scaffold was calculated according to the following equation:
where w1 is the weight of wet scaffold after soaking in water, and w2 is the weight of dry scaffold before soaking in water.
2.4 Mechanical testing
The compressive strength and Young’s modulus of scaffolds with size of Ф10×10mm were measured by a mechanical testing machine (CMT4204, MTS). Compressive force was performed in z direction of scaffold with load cell of 20 kN and cross-head speed of 1 mm/min. Young’s modulus of scaffold was calculated according to the slope of strain-stress curves in the elastic deformation region. Five samples for each type of scaffold were tested for mean and standard deviation calculation.
2.5 Cell culture and RT-PCR experiment
The rat bone marrow stem cells (rBMSC) were isolated from 30-day-old male Sprague-Dawley (SD) rat using an established method [28]. The fifth passage cells were used for the experiments. Proliferation experiments: to monitor the proliferation behavior of cells in the 3D printed scaffolds (Ф5×2 mm), 300 μL medium containing cells (cell density of 1×105 cells/mL) was seeded into each scaffold. These cell-laden samples were then cultured with Dulbecco's Modified Eagle Medium (DMEM, Thermo Fisher Scientific)
AC
C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS, GIBCO), 100 U/ml penicillin (SIGMA), and 100 μg/ml streptomycin (SIGMA) at 37 °C and 5% CO2. The cell number was determined by Cell Counting Kit-8 (CCK8, Dojindo). After 2, 4 and 8 days of culture, the samples were washed by PBS for 3 times, and then 200μL DMEM and 10μL CCK8 was added to each sample. After incubation of 2 hours at 37 oC, the absorbance at 450nm was measured by a microplate reader (Thermo Fisher Scientific) (n=4). RT-PCR experiments: to evaluate the gene expression level of osteogenic differentiation, RT-PCR was performed with osteogenic biomarkers including ALP, OPN, OCN and RUNX2 using the expression level 18S as a standard. The sequences of the primer pairs for each gene are listed in Table 1. After one and two weeks of culture, the total RNA of these laden samples was isolated by Trizol (SIGMA), and cDNA was collected by cDNA Synthesis kit (Thermo Fisher Scientific). The subsequent PCR reactions were performed using SYBER green mixtum (Thermo Fisher Scientific), according to the manufacturer’s instructions. All PCR reactions were run for 45 cycles (n=4).
Table 1. Primer sequences used in gene expression analysis.
Genes Forward (5'-3') Reverse (5'-3')
ALP CAGTGGTATTGTAGGTGCTGTGGT GACGGTGTCGTAGCCTTCTGG
OPN CCAGCCAAGGACCAACTACA AGTGTTTGCTGTAATGCGCC
OCN GCACCACCGTTTAGGGCAT CGTTCCTCATCTGGACTTTATTTTG
Runx2 CTTCCAGACCAGCAGCACTCCAT CCATCAGCGTCAACACCATCATT
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
2.6 Protein adsorption
The three types of scaffolds with same morphology (lattice) and size (10×10×5 mm) were prepared according to the previous description. Each scaffold was placed in a 15 mL tube, and then 3 mL DMEM containing 10% FBS was added in each tube for immersing the sample completely. Then, the tubes containing scaffolds were gently shaken at 37 °C. After incubation for 1 and 5 h, 50 µL medium was taken to quantify the total protein by BCA assay according to the manufacturer’s instructions. Briefly, BCA solution was added to each well and incubated for 30 min at 37 ºC. The absorbance at wavelength of 562 nm was measured in a microplate reader (Thermo Fisher Scientific). Four samples for each type of scaffold were measured.
2.7 Statistical analysis
All data were expressed as mean±standard deviation (SD). One-way ANOVA was performed to analyze the difference, and p< 0.05 was considered to be statistically significant.

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text:
3.1 Preparation of scaffolds
The prepared bioinks consisting of concentrated alginate/gelatin gels and phosphate ions were excellent for extrusion-based 3D printing through adjusting the printing parameters including printing speed, pressure and temperature. Scaffolds were able to keep the structural integrity without deformation and collapse due to the sufficient mechanical strength from highly concentrated gels. When the printed scaffolds (0.1
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
and 0.5 M Na2HPO4) were transferred to CaCl2 solution, milky white materials were produced on the surface of scaffolds and also in the solution immediately. However, there was no apparent visible change in the control group (0.1 M NaCl) (Figure 1a). Calcium ions worked as the crosslinker for the gelation of alginate. Meanwhile, they were also consumed by the reaction between calcium and phosphate for the mineral formation. The reaction mainly took place at the surface of alginate/gelatin struts, which is the interface between calcium and phosphate ions. Phosphate ions were fast consumed at the surface, and then the others diffused from the center of struts to surface. Meanwhile, the diffusion of calcium ions from the surface to inside of struts was inhibited by the fast formed apatite layer. Furthermore, calcium ions were partly consumed by the crosslinking of alginate. Therefore, the nano apatite was mainly formed on the surface of alginate/gelatin scaffolds [20]. After gelatin was crosslinked, the alginate/gelatin composites formed interpenetrating networks achieving mechanical integrity [29].
3.2 Characterization of scaffolds
The microscopic images showed that the surfaces of mineralized scaffolds (0.1 and 0.5 M Na2HPO4) were fully covered by a layer of white materials compared to control sample (Figure 1). SEM images demonstrated that the mineralized scaffolds (0.1 and 0.5 M) were completely covered by a layer of nano apatite on the surface, while the control scaffold presented a smooth surface without any nano apatite coating. EDS analysis showed that strong Ca and P peak signals were observed in mineralized scaffolds (0.1 and 0.5 M). As control, the alginate/gelatin scaffold (0.1 M NaCl) only
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
showed Ca peak, but without P signal (Figure 2). FTIR spectra revealed that the bands of P-O bending vibration (560 and 604 cm-1) [30] were clearly appeared in mineralized scaffolds (0.1 and 0.5 M), compared to alginate/gelatin scaffolds (control sample) (Figure 3). All received data indicated that a layer of nano apatite was successfully deposited on the whole surface of alginate/gelatin scaffolds in this study. TG data showed that the weight loss of alginate/gelatin (0.1 M NaCl) and mineralized scaffolds (0.1 M and 0.5 M) were 75.3%, 72.5% and 66.8%, respectively (Figure 4). Therefore, it can be calculated that the amount of apatite in mineralized scaffolds were 2.8% (0.1 M) and 8.5% (0.5 M), respectively. The amount of deposited minerals was able to be adjusted by controlling the amount of Na2HPO4 in the bioinks.
3.3 Swelling ratio
Dry scaffolds were incubated in deionized water to test their swelling behavior. The results showed that the three types of scaffolds presented no apparent difference in swelling ratio, and the deposited minerals had no significant influence on the swelling ability (Figure 5). The main reason is that alginate and gelatin are hydrogels with excellent water adsorption capacity [31], and theminerals were mainly deposited on the surface of scaffolds with limited amount (2.8% and 8.5%). Therefore, the minerals occupied limited spaces within the alginate/gelatin matrices, having no significant influence on the swelling ratio of scaffolds.
3.4 Mechanical testing
The compressive strength and modulus of 3D printed alginate/gelatin scaffolds with/without nano apatite coating were tested. The received data (Figure 6) showed
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
that the compressive strength of mineralized scaffolds (20.7±4.7 MPa for 0.1 M scaffolds and 23.9±1.5 MPa for 0.5 M scaffolds) was slightly higher than that of control scaffolds (18.8±5.8 MPa). However, the Young’s modulus of mineralized scaffolds (119±26, 135±36 MPa) was significantly higher compared to that of control scaffolds (62±5.8 MPa). It seems that although the homogeneous minerals were mainly deposited on the surface of scaffolds, they still increased the density of alginate/gelatin struts, which might be the main contribution for the pronounced increase in Young’s modulus. Additionally, concentrated alginate/gelatin composites had dense structures after dural crosslinking and drying [11]. Thus, the compressive strength and modulus of concentrated alginate/gelatin scaffolds were significant higher than those of scaffolds prepared by low concentration of alginate/gelatin [32,33]. Furthermore, the photographs showed that the three types of scaffolds presented good toughness and they still maintained their bulk morphologies without collapsing after 30% of compression. The good toughness is also an important mechanical feature for porous scaffolds using for bone tissue engineering [34].
3.5 Proliferation and differentiation of cells on scaffolds
The fabricated bone scaffold having bioactive surface is crucially important for stimulating the proliferation and osteogenic differentiation of stem cells [35].The proliferation rate of cells on the fabricated scaffolds was measured by using the CCK8 kit up to 8 days of culture. The data showed that the cell number was significantly increased during 8 days of culture on the three types of scaffolds, which indicated the good biocompatebility of the selected materials in this study. Moreover, the
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
proliferation rate of cells on nano apatite coated alginate/gelatin scaffolds was significantly higher than that on alginate/gelatin scaffolds (Figure 7). RT-PCR analysis showed that the nano apatite coated alginate/gelatin scaffolds triggered more pronounced upregulation of osteogenic marker genes (OPN, OCN, Runx2 and ALP), compared to those alginate/gelatin scaffolds without apatite coating (control sample) (Figure 8). All the received data indicated that homogeneous nano apatite coating on the surface of alginate/gelatin could promote the adhesion, proliferation and osteogenic differentiation of rBMSCs. Bone-related genes (ALP, OPN, OCN and Runx2) are the key markers in determining osteogenic differentiation [36]. It is well known that ALP is the pivotal marker for early mineralization [37,38], and Runx2 is a key transcription factor for osteogenic differentiation and mineralization [39]. Furthermore, OPN and OCN are both critical markers for osteogenic differentiation [40,41]. Apatite coating provides biomimetic extracellular matrix (ECM) for the survival of stem cells in a natural bone environment. It has been indicated that HA can promote the expression of endogenous BMP-2, which then enhanced the specific ALP activity in stem cells [42,43].
3.6 Protein adsorption
The protein adsorption on scaffolds was tested by incubating scaffolds into DMEM containing 10% FBS over 1 and 5 h. The received data (Figure 9) revealed that both types of mineralized scaffolds (0.1 M and 0.5 M) had higher protein adsorption compared to control scaffolds without nano apatite coating. In addition, the amounts of adsorbed proteins on mineralized scaffolds were increased with the increase of the
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
amounts of minerals. It is well known that several factors would influence protein adsorption on scaffolds including hydrophobicity [44], surface energy, electrostatic strength, topography and specific surface area [45]. In this work, the increased roughness on the surface owing to the nano apatite coating might be one of the main factors for the enhancement of the protein adsorption on the scaffolds. Additionally, the porous structures of the deposited nano apatite also contributed to the increase of protein adsorption [13]. It has been demonstrated that the cell adhesion on the surface of scaffolds/implants was influenced by protein adsorption [46]. Once the scaffolds were implanted in vivo, proteins were adsorbed on the surface rapidly. The adsorbed proteins serve as ligands binding to the receptors on cell membrane leading to cells adhesion [47].This might be one of the contributions to the improved cell adhesion and proliferation on the nano apatite coated scaffolds.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
In this study, alginate/gelatin interpenetrating scaffolds with homogeneous nano apatite coating were fabricated via 3D printing and in situ mineralization. The thickness of nano apatite coating was able to be controlled by adjusting the amount of phosphate in bioinks. TheYoung’s modulus of alginate/gelatin scaffold was increased due to the deposition of nano apatite. In addition, nano apatite coating significantly stimulated the proliferation and osteogenic differentiation of rBMSCs. Moreover, the deposited nano apatite increased the protein adsorption on the surface of scaffolds. Overall, the prepared alginate/gelatin scaffold with nano apatite coating might be a promising candidate for bone tissue engineering application.

EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R

Graphical abstract
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
Highlights
 Concentrated alginate/gelatin interpenetrating scaffolds with
homogeneous nano apatite coating were fabricated via 3D printing and in situ mineralization.
 3D printing precisely controlled the morphology of scaffolds, and in situ
mineralization was efficient to produce homogeneously distributed nano apatite coating on the entire surface of scaffolds.
 The nano apatite coated alginate/gelatin scaffolds exhibited enhanced
Young’s modulus and protein adsorption.
 The nano apatite coating stimulated the proliferation and osteogenic
differentiation of rat bone marrow stem cells on the scaffolds.

referenceMentions.context: Various biomaterials including bioceramics and polymers have been utilized to prepare scaffolds for bone tissue engineering [2].
For instance, synthetic polymers such as poly(lactic acid) (PLA) [3], poly(ɛ-caprolactone) (PCL) [4] and poly
For instance, synthetic polymers such as poly(lactic acid) (PLA) [3], poly(ɛ-caprolactone) (PCL) [4] and poly
(lactic-co-glycolic) acid (PLGA) [5] with good biocompatibility and suitable mechanical strength have been developed as bone scaffolds using various techniques.

Additionally, natural biopolymers such as collagen, gelatin and chitosan with excellent biocompatibility and abundant of cell recognition sites are promising candidates for tissue engineering application [6,7].

Additionally, natural biopolymers such as collagen, gelatin and chitosan with excellent biocompatibility and abundant of cell recognition sites are promising candidates for tissue engineering application [6,7].

metadata.abstractText: Biomimetic nano apatite/polymer composite scaffolds with good mechanical properties and desirable bioactivity are promising for bone tissue engineering. Here, concentrated alginate/gelatin scaffolds with homogeneous nano apatite coating were developed utilizing 3D printing and in situ mineralization. The thickness of nano apatite coating was controlled by adjusting the amount of phosphate ions in the printing inks. The alginate/gelatin scaffolds with uniform nano apatite coating had 2-fold higher Young’s modulus compared with the scaffolds without apatite coating. In addition, nano apatite coating significantly stimulated the proliferation and osteogenic differentiation of rat bone marrow stem cells. Furthermore, nano apatite coating increased the protein adsorption on the surface of scaffolds. The fabricated biomimetic nano apatite/hydrogel composite scaffolds would be potential candidates for bone tissue engineering.
